text: One of my favorite rules for convertible words is the rule for words ending I-O-N.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This is an extremely useful rule.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Words ending I-O-N are the same in English and Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Just in Spanish they have the accent on the end.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, for example, in English we have opinion and in Spanish you're going to pronounce syllable by syllable making sure that you're pronouncing the vowels as they're written and you're going to put the accent on the end.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Then you pronounce the S because we don't write SH.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now if it's SH-N, T-I-O-N, if we have SH-N, it's going to be C-I-O-N in Spanish and this C-I-O-N is pronounced S-I-O-N like an S in most of the Spanish-speaking world or in most of Spain it's pronounced T-I-O-N.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So you can choose if you have a particular affiliation for Spain, you can make this TH.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If not, I suggest using the S sound because a majority of Spanish speakers are using this sound and it's also much easier.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But if you want to ask for a beer, for example, with the S sound you're going to ask for a cerveza.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you're going to ask using the TH sound you're going to ask for cerveza.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So I would suggest unless you have a particular affiliation with Spain or you particularly want to be practicing with some Spanish friends or whatever to use the SO sound.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So you have a word like organization that Z as well is going to sound like an S or a TH.

text: So this is actually called language transfer.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this is negative language transfer.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Things that come from English affecting your Spanish, which are not part of Spanish, are negative language transfer.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And what is useful from English, so like these convertible words that we are using as far as language learning is concerned, this is positive language transfer.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So part of our journey here is to identify what is negative language transfer and what is positive language transfer.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And using both to our advantage.
